awd_titl_txt: Curatorial Stewardship of the Antarctic and the Southern Ocean National Collection of Rock and Sediment Cores at the OSU Marine and Geology Repository
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description

The Antarctic core collection, curated at Florida State University since 1963, is one of the world?s premier marine geology collections. Consisting of irreplaceable sediment cores, this archive has greatly advanced the understanding of the Earth system, past and present, and will remain critical to future studies of the Earth. Given Oregon State University?s (OSU) leadership in marine research and long track record providing state-of-the-art curatorial services through the OSU Marine and Geology Repository, this facility will provide world-class curatorial stewardship of the Antarctic core collection for decades to come. The Antarctic core collection will be co-located and co-managed with the current OSU collection in a single modern repository and analytical facility. The combined collection will contain more than 30 km of refrigerated sediment core from the world?s oceans and will be housed in a new 33,000 SFT facility purchased in 2009 by OSU and upgraded in 2016-17. The total refrigerated space can hold both collections comfortably and has at least five decades of expansion space.

The co-location and co-management of these two collections, paired with a modern suite of analytical facilities, will lead to greater collaboration, cross-pollination of ideas, and availability of enhanced technical services and capabilities for a growing user group that increasingly relies on marine sediments. The facility will employ a comprehensive community interaction plan that takes advantage of the new OSU Marine and Geology Repository building with a 32-person seminar room, its large 1,044 square foot core lab, and ten adjoining analytical laboratories, which will provide scientific and experiential learning opportunities for students, the general public, and the Earth Sciences research community. The facility will organize small group meetings, sampling parties and summer schools that will complement ongoing support for teaching, training and learning through the use of the repository in graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 classes and Research Experience for Undergraduate programs. The repository is open to the general public for tours and presentations, and the data products derived from the facility will be disseminated via the repository website at http://osu-mgr.org/ and other national databases.

Technical Description

The Antarctic and the Southern Ocean National Collection of Rock and Sediment Cores currently housed at Florida State University will be relocated to Oregon State University (OSU) and housed along with the OSU Marine and Geology Repository. Oregon State University investigators will co-manage the Antarctic core collection and the Marine and Geology Repository as a single modern repository and analytical facility. The combined collection will be housed a new 33,000 square foot building with refrigerated space that can hold both collections with approximately five decades of expansion space. The co-location and co-management of these two collections offers unique curatorial synergies, cost savings, and improved capabilities to support both the research and educational needs of a wider marine and Antarctic communities. The facility will house a 32-person seminar room, a large 1,044 square foot core lab that allows layout, inspection and examination of cores, and adjoining analytical laboratories that will provide quantitative analysis as well as experiential learning opportunities for students.

por.por_cntn:
The National Collection of Geological Rock and Sediment Cores from Antarctica and the Southern Oceans (hereafter called the Antarctic Core Collection or ACC) was held at Florida State University (FSU) from the mid 1960's until 2018 and is one of the world’s premier geological collections. The wealth of geological information and climate data contained within the ACC collection are a critical asset to the scientific community, for example, in gauging Earth’s future environment and climate. As such this collection will continue to attract strong attention both nationally and internationally. 

Since August 2018, the ACC is housed in our new OSU-MGR facility obtained in 2009 by Oregon State University (OSU) and upgraded for $6.5M in 2017-2018 by OSU and the College of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences (CEOAS). The ACC was moved from Florida to Oregon in July-August 2018 and has been recurated into the OSU-MGR in August-September 2018; the MGG core collection that has been curated since the early 1970's by OSU on behalf of NSF Marine Geology and Geophysics was moved into the new facility directly following the ACC collection in October-November 2018; and all instrumentation from ACC and MGG were combined and reinstalled in the new OSU-MGR facility over the same period. The grand opening of the new facility housing the combined ACC and MGG collections was in January 2019.

The co-location and co-management of these two premier core collections offers a unique opportunity by providing (i) curatorial synergies, (ii) cost savings, and (iii) improved services that supports a wider community and that will lead to greater collaboration among marine geology and Antarctic researchers and allows for crosspollination of ideas and techniques to address some of the most significant Earth, Ocean, and Antarctic science questions that only marine sediment cores can answer.

The OSU-MGR has been providing subsamples to many dozens of unique requestrors from many institutions domestically and internationally. For example, since January 2021, more than 4,500 samples have been distributed to more than 25 researchres or students from 5 international and 29 domestic research institutions. Of these 49% were from older scientific seagoing expeditions that happened more than 5 years ago. In addition, we also have carried out non-destructive analyses of sediment cores upon request of 13 external to OSU researchers for close to 700 m of sediment core, while the OSU-MGR has collected an extra 4,200 m of these data to be made available to the overall community via our website and database.

The OSU-MGR ACC holdings were increased with the addition of new sediment cores from three recent marine coring cruises that collected 45 cores. The OSU-MGR ACC holding now totals 24,359.6 m from 5,408 cores.

The OSU-MGR continues to take the lead in digitization with improvements in our current database and App. Our capabilities increased with a switch to a new cloud server, making searches signficantly faster. Users can now query the collections based on cruise, core or ship names, PI name, location, institution, etc. and see related datasets and basic metadata profiles on landing pages. We have also made improvements to our map-based interface to link between these landing pages for each core and sample in the collection.

Now that we have a live link established between our database and our website for serving data, we can move forward over the next five years on additions to the OSU-MGR App to assist with day-to-day operational needs, new features to add to the website, and API services for interoperability improvements. In house, we aim to finalize the process for printing labels directly from the App, for core sections, rocks, and sample requests. We also plan to import our inventory of previous sample requests, as well as create an interface for recording sample requests collected by curators and visitors using the App. For the website, we aim to establish a data processing step that will allow us to better serve CT scans, add features for downloading batches of data, and improve our methods for sharing related publications. Additionally, we will assign IGSNs to our entire collection using the App, and link to other relevant datasets using the FIESTA Core Data Repository (CDR) as that system evolves.

 


Last Modified: 08/27/2023
Modified by: Anthony Koppers
